question: Will you manage groupings/ pods/ bubbles/ networks?
description:
One of the most effective COVID-19 controls is limiting social networks. If someone who is infected has contact with 10 people, they are more likely to transmit the virus than someone who had contact with only 5 people. If each of those original 10 people have contact with another 10 people, the original case could potentially infect up to 100 people within 2 steps. If that grouping of 10 has no outside contacts, the number of infections is limited to 10.
In a school setting, what does a pod look like? It might be an entire class, which would only interact with others in the class. It might be a small group of 3-5 students who work together, attend the same classes, and agree not to mix outside their pod. The important thing to consider is that the final pod size includes all contacts of the members of the pod; creating pods and then letting them mix with multiple other pods will defeat the purpose. Once formed, the group has to agree to maintain separation from others.
Regardless of choice, you should have a policy around specialists providing services within the school who will be meeting with individual students, such as counselors and speech therapists. If possible, provide plexiglass barriers between specialist and student, move these meetings to larger rooms with more ventilation and space, and/or move these meetings to a virtual setting.

answers.description:
One of the simplest podding groups is classes. This is especially useful in the pre-K to 5 range, where classes are normally maintained for the full school day. In higher grade levels, the maintenance of an entire class as a pod would be more logistically challenging.
You will need policies around the movement of adults between rooms, so as to not counteract the pod structure. This could include assistants, substitutes, and subject-specific teachers (such as music or art). Where possible, limit the number of people moving between rooms.

One method that has been used successfully in France is to form small pods (3-4 students). While these pods may attend class with other pods, each pod will maintain distance from the others. For instance, students within a pod might be able to sit at the same table, share sports equipment, and move through halls together. In that way, each case would only be in close contact with 2-3 other students.
The formation of these pods will require a number of policy decisions. Will they be single-gender or mixed? Will students select their own group, or will they be assigned? How would regrouping work if conflict arises?
In higher grade levels, pods should have matching class schedules. Likewise, pods should take into account extracurricular activities to minimize mixing outside the classroom.

Within higher grade levels, it may be easier to ensure simply no mixing between grade levels. That could mean that courses in which grade levels usually mix be divided so that only one grade level is present at a time. Alternatively, courses could be limited to particular grade levels.

It could be possible to form groups, larger than pods but smaller than grade levels, that would be able to move through classes together (or, preferably, stay in a single room and have teachers rotate).

question: How will lunchroom/lunch be handled
description:
Lunch is a high-risk time, as eating requires removing masks. Typical lunchrooms do not allow proper spacing, which is intensified as masks are removed.
Remember that traffic flow around lunchrooms will be important to manage. If possible, set up a one-way flow so that student groups will not pass each other.

answers.description: If scheduling allows, avoiding students being present in the building over lunch time would be preferred. This could mean a morning-only schedule or a morning/afternoon alternation.

If lunch times could be spread over a longer period, it would be possible to decrease the number of people in a lunchroom at a given time. It is not advisable to do this by shortening lunch times for the sake of healthy eating times.

Other large, well-ventilated rooms (such as gyms and auditoriums) might be used as expanded lunch space to ensure low density. If weather allows, outdoor eating areas are a good choice. This will require more observers for lunchtimes.

Especially if classes are considered to be pods, having them remain in a classroom for lunch might be an option. Remember, though, that when masks are removed more space should be used and higher ventilation standards are needed. Another drawback to this approach is that teachers would no longer have lunch as a rest/prep period. Teachers might also object to the additional exposure associated with being in a room with unmasked students, as this is a greater risk. This will likely need union discussions.

question: Will there be recess?
description:
If students have a recess period, the ideal would be to maintain groupings/pods for that time. Shared outdoor equipment is low risk as long as distance and good hygiene are maintained and regular cleaning is used, especially with older students. Indoors, caution should be used with shared equipment and space.
Masks should be worn during recess, and distancing should be maintained. Students should wash hands before and after recess periods. Flow into and out of recess space should be one way, to avoid cross-traffic.

question: What structural changes are you making?

answers.description: If transmission is high in your community, it may be necessary to remain virtual. In this case, you will want to ensure access to all students. This may include providing tablets or laptops, wi-fi hotspots, and technical assistance.

You may wish to allow for some in-person students while others remain virtual. In this case, you will want to ensure access to all virtual students. This may include providing tablets or laptops, wi-fi hotspots, and technical assistance.

It is possible to limit group size by having students alternate between virtual and in-person classes. For example, the A group would be in-person on Monday and Thursday while the B group would be in-person on Tuesday and Friday, with Wednesday as a cleaning day. Alternately, the A group could be in-person in mornings, while the B group is in-person in afternoons, which has the advantage of avoiding in-school lunch but the disadvantage of doubling the transportation burden per day.
In this setup, you will want to ensure access to all students. This may include providing tablets or laptops, wi-fi hotspots, and technical assistance.

This is a schedule in which students are in person 4 days every other week, then virtual the other days. The idea is that the 10 days between in-person sessions acts as an informal quarantine period for any exposures that happen during the 4 in-person days. This could also be used with alternating schedules, such that half the students are in-person for 4 days one week, then the other half of the students are in-person the next week. Remember that this will only be effective if students are not congregating outside school.

If you are fully in-person, there will be teachers and parents who are uncomfortable with the risk. You will need a process to support those who are high-risk. You will also need a decision process for when to revert to hybrid or virtual teaching, based on local transmission, availability of staff, or evidence of within-school spread.

question: Who will be allowed to be in-person?

answers.description: You may wish to limit in-person students to those who are unable to participate in virtual class. This could be self-reported or based on assessment from teachers, administrators, or social workers. Potential reasons for requiring in-person instruction include: inability to connect to internet, lack of secure space to attend class, lack of guardianship during class time.

You may also allow parents to self-select for virtual or in-person class. This could be done via a web survey, a paper survey, or even phone calls to individual families. This may result in uneven distribution of in-person student numbers across grades and classes.

question: Process for changing in-person vs. virtual status
description: How will parents request a change from in-person to virtual or vice versa? You may want to limit this change to only allowing one change per semester, or requiring virtual students to remain so. You should not limit the ability of students to change to virtual, as this choice may be taken based on changes in family risk.

answers.answer: Teachers managing virtual and in-person classrooms together
answers.description: You will need to ensure IT support within classrooms, and train your teachers on managing dual processes.

answers.answer: Virtual classrooms be separated from in-person
answers.description: You will need to assign teachers to virtual or in-person based on student numbers and types in each group. This may need to consider the preferences of the teachers, including identifying high-risk teachers who may need to remain virtual.

question: Movement
description: While much has been made of the 15-minute contact time, there is risk associated with shorter contact periods, especially when they involve congregations of large numbers in tight spaces. That makes movement through the school a critical control point to minimize transmission.

question: How will you minimize contact at entry and exit points?

answers.description: One option is to bring your smaller groups in at separate times. This may be logistically difficult, however, especially with transportation issues and multi-group families.
If you have multiple entry and exit points, you may want to designate a specific entrance and exit for each group, so as to minimize mixing between your groups.
If you have lines at entrance and exit times, it will be important to at a minimum enforce spacing between individuals.

question: How will you minimize contact in hallways?

answers.description: You can minimize face-to-face contacts by restricting movement direction.
It is best to limit the number of people in a hallway at one time. You can do this by scheduling groups to different movement times, although this could become logistically difficult.

The best option is to limit the amount of movement within the building. This could be done in higher grade levels through having teachers move instead of students. In earlier grades, this might be through keeping all class activities within a single room.

question: Which extracurricular activities will you allow?

Will you allow your teams to compete? This should depend on the level of community spread and your comfort with the precautions taken by other teams.
